items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump imposed sweeping sanctions Wednesday on Russian oil giants Rosneft and Lukoil, expressing frustration over stalled peace talks with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine.
items.content: US President Donald Trump imposed sweeping sanctions Wednesday on Russian oil giants Rosneft and Lukoil, expressing frustration over stalled peace talks with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine.

items.title: Trump sanctions Russian oil companies as his efforts to end Ukraine war falter
items.standfirst: President Trump took a step that he had not taken during his second term and imposed new sanctions on Russia. The Treasury Department announced the sanctions on Russia’s two largest oil companies and accused Putin of not taking Trump’s pursuit of peace in Ukraine seriously. Nick Schifrin reports.
items.content: President Trump took a step that he had not taken during his second term and imposed new sanctions on Russia. items.title: US imposes sanctions on Russian oil over Putin’s ‘refusal’ to end war in Ukraine
items.standfirst: Trump administration hardens stance against the Kremlin day after cancelling a planned summit with Russian leaderThe US has sanctioned Rosneft and Lukoil, Russia’s two largest oil companies, as the Trump administration increased pressure on the Kremlin to negotiate an end to its war against Ukraine.The sanctions were the first against Russia since Donald Trump returned to the White House in January, and were targeted to cut key revenues from oil sales that finance the Russian war machine. Continue reading...
items.content: Trump administration hardens stance against the Kremlin day after cancelling a planned summit with Russian leaderThe US has sanctioned Rosneft and Lukoil, Russia’s two largest oil companies, as the Trump administration increased pressure on the Kremlin to negotiate an end to its war against Ukraine.The sanctions were the first against Russia since Donald Trump returned to the White House in January, and were targeted to cut key revenues from oil sales that finance the Russian war machine. items.title: U.S. sanctions Russia's two largest oil companies
items.standfirst: The Treasury Department announced new sanctions targeting Russia’s oil sector Wednesday, the day after President Donald Trump confirmed that a planned meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss Russia's war with Ukraine was off. “Now is the time to stop the killing and for an immediate ceasefire,” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in a statement.
items.content: The Treasury Department announced new sanctions targeting Russia’s oil sector Wednesday, the day after President Donald Trump confirmed that a planned meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss Russia's war with Ukraine was off. “Now is the time to stop the killing and for an immediate ceasefire,” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in a statement.

items.title: Trump-Putin summit 'on hold' as Kremlin sticks to hard line on Ukraine
items.standfirst: The Kremlin denied Tuesday that it was holding up President Donald Trump’s push to end the war in Ukraine ahead of possible talks with Vladimir Putin.
items.content: The Kremlin denied Tuesday that it was holding up President Donald Trump’s push to end the war in Ukraine ahead of possible talks with Vladimir Putin.

ai_summary: The US announced new sanctions on Rosneft and Lukoil, Russia's largest oil companies, due to the Ukraine war.
These sanctions are part of Donald Trump's effort to punish energy companies funding the Kremlin's war.
The sanctions aim to pressure Russia to negotiate and end the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.
Indian refiners are reviewing Russian oil contracts following the announcement of US sanctions.
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen appreciated the US sanctions on Russian oil companies.

items.title: US kills three in second strike on alleged drug boat in the Pacific

items.content: This is the ninth US strike on alleged drug boats near Latin America, and the second in the Pacific.

items.title: US military kills five people in strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in Pacific
items.standfirst: Latest strikes were off coast of Colombia, while seven previous attacks in Caribbean killed at least 32The US military has for the first time attacked and destroyed two boats on the Pacific side of South America, as part of its ongoing and controversial fight against what it says are drug-trafficking activities.The strikes – on Tuesday night and then early on Wednesday – killed five people according the US defense secretary, Pete Hegseth. Previous attacks have hit seven vessels in the Caribbean and killed at least 32 people. Continue reading...
items.content: Latest strikes were off coast of Colombia, while seven previous attacks in Caribbean killed at least 32The US military has for the first time attacked and destroyed two boats on the Pacific side of South America, as part of its ongoing and controversial fight against what it says are drug-trafficking activities.The strikes – on Tuesday night and then early on Wednesday – killed five people according the US defense secretary, Pete Hegseth. Previous attacks have hit seven vessels in the Caribbean and killed at least 32 people. Continue reading...

items.title: Two killed by US strike on alleged drug-trafficking boat in Pacific Ocean
items.standfirst: A strike launched by the US military killed two people on an alleged drug-trafficking vessel in the Pacific Ocean, US Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth said on Wednesday. The latest strike marks an expansion of what US President Donald Trump described as an "armed conflict" with South America's drug cartels that has, until now, targeted vessels in the Caribbean.
items.content: A strike launched by the US military killed two people on an alleged drug-trafficking vessel in the Pacific Ocean, US Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth said on Wednesday. The latest strike marks an expansion of what US President Donald Trump described as an "armed conflict" with South America's drug cartels that has, until now, targeted vessels in the Caribbean.

ai_summary: The US military conducted its ninth strike on alleged drug boats near Latin America.
This was the second strike in the Pacific, with the first seven in the Caribbean.
The strikes off the coast of Colombia killed five people, according to the US defense secretary.
Previous attacks in the Caribbean resulted in the deaths of at least thirty-two individuals.
The strikes signal an expansion of the US military campaign against drug trafficking.

clusters.title: Louvre director recognises jewel theft failures, says she offered to resign
clusters.neutral_headline: Louvre Director Admits Security Failures After Heist

items.title: Louvre director recognises jewel theft failures, says she offered to resign
items.standfirst: Laurence des Cars told France's Senate the heist exposed the museum's camera shortage and other security 'weaknesses'.
items.content: Laurence des Cars told France's Senate the heist exposed the museum's camera shortage and other security 'weaknesses'.

items.title: Louvre director admits 'insufficient' camera coverage after heist
items.standfirst: The director of the Louvre on Wednesday admitted to inadequate camera surveillance of the museum's outside walls, three days after thieves robbed it of prize jewels in a brazen daytime heist. But Laurence des Cars said that a diamond- and emerald-studded crown that the burglars damaged and dropped as they fled on Sunday could be restored. FRANCE 24's Yinka Oyetade reports.
items.content: The director of the Louvre on Wednesday admitted to inadequate camera surveillance of the museum's outside walls, three days after thieves robbed it of prize jewels in a brazen daytime heist. But Laurence des Cars said that a diamond- and emerald-studded crown that the burglars damaged and dropped as they fled on Sunday could be restored. FRANCE 24's Yinka Oyetade reports.

items.title: No camera covered Louvre wall where jewel thieves broke in, director says
items.standfirst: Laurence des Cars said there was only one camera pointing on the gallery which was robbed.
items.content: Laurence des Cars said there was only one camera pointing on the gallery which was robbed.

items.title: Louvre director admits 'insufficient' security and says she offered to resign after jewel heist
items.standfirst: The director of the Louvre on Wednesday told the French Senate there was "insufficient" security camera coverage at the instutution and that she had offered her resignation – which was refused by France's culture minister – after an audacious heist on Sunday saw thieves break into the museum and steal €88 million worth of jewels.
items.content: The director of the Louvre on Wednesday told the French Senate there was "insufficient" security camera coverage at the instutution and that she had offered her resignation – which was refused by France's culture minister – after an audacious heist on Sunday saw thieves break into the museum and steal €88 million worth of jewels.

ai_summary: The Louvre director acknowledged insufficient camera coverage after a recent jewel heist.
The director, Laurence des Cars, admitted to security weaknesses in the museum.
There was only one camera covering the wall where the thieves broke into the museum.
The director offered to resign, but the French culture minister refused her offer.
The stolen jewels were worth approximately €88 million.

items.content: Alleged trafficker, Zhi Dong Zhang, who had escaped Mexican authorities in July, was arrested in Cuba,

items.title: Cuba arrests alleged Chinese fentanyl kingpin who escaped custody in Mexico
items.standfirst: Zhi Dong Zhang, known by alias ‘Brother Wang’, is also wanted by US and has alleged ties to Mexican drug cartelsCuba has arrested an alleged Chinese fentanyl kingpin who escaped custody in Mexico in July and is also wanted by the US, Mexican security sources told AFP on Wednesday.Zhi Dong Zhang, known by the alias “Brother Wang” and with alleged ties to Mexico’s Sinaloa and Jalisco New Generation drug cartels, will remain in Cuba awaiting a decision on his possible extradition, the sources added. Continue reading...
items.content: Zhi Dong Zhang, known by alias ‘Brother Wang’, is also wanted by US and has alleged ties to Mexican drug cartelsCuba has arrested an alleged Chinese fentanyl kingpin who escaped custody in Mexico in July and is also wanted by the US, Mexican security sources told AFP on Wednesday.Zhi Dong Zhang, known by the alias “Brother Wang” and with alleged ties to Mexico’s Sinaloa and Jalisco New Generation drug cartels, will remain in Cuba awaiting a decision on his possible extradition, the sources added. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Cuba arrested Zhi Dong Zhang, an alleged Chinese fentanyl kingpin.
Zhang escaped Mexican authorities in July and is also wanted by the US.
He is believed to have ties to Mexican drug cartels.
Zhang will remain in Cuba pending a decision on extradition.
The arrest was confirmed by Mexican security sources.

items.title: Democrats call on Rubio to help secure release of Palestinian-American teen held in Israeli prison
items.standfirst: Group of 27 Congress members wrote to Marco Rubio to call for ‘swift release’ of 16-year-old Mohammed IbrahimUS politics live – latest updatesMore than two dozen Democratic lawmakers have written to the secretary of state, Marco Rubio, and the US ambassador to Israel urging them to help secure the release of Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian-American citizen who has been held in Israeli military detention for nearly eight months.Ibrahim, a dual Palestinian-American teenager from Florida, was arrested in a raid on his family’s West Bank home in February when he was 15 years old. Israeli forces allegedly blindfolded and handcuffed the boy at 3am, according to the letter led by senators Chris Van Hollen and Jeff Merkley and representatives Kathy Castor and Maxwell Frost. Continue reading...
items.content: Group of 27 Congress members wrote to Marco Rubio to call for ‘swift release’ of 16-year-old Mohammed IbrahimUS politics live – latest updatesMore than two dozen Democratic lawmakers have written to the secretary of state, Marco Rubio, and the US ambassador to Israel urging them to help secure the release of Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian-American citizen who has been held in Israeli military detention for nearly eight months.Ibrahim, a dual Palestinian-American teenager from Florida, was arrested in a raid on his family’s West Bank home in February when he was 15 years old. Israeli forces allegedly blindfolded and handcuffed the boy at 3am, according to the letter led by senators Chris Van Hollen and Jeff Merkley and representatives Kathy Castor and Maxwell Frost. Continue reading...
